answers.title: Why does my moment.js not calculate time in different timezone based on given timestamp?
answers.body:
When you pass a plain number into the moment constructor, it expects that to be in terms of milliseconds since the Unix epoch. The value you gave as an example would appear to be in terms of seconds.

You can do either one of these:

// multiply by 1000
moment(1443646527 * 1000).tz("America/Chicago").format('h:mm:ss A')

Or:

// use the unix function
moment.unix(1443646527).tz("America/Chicago").format('h:mm:ss A')

With either, you will get the expected answer "3:55:27 PM".

answers.title: Polymer refresh the property's value which is calculated by a method
answers.body:
The error that you are seeing is not caused by dataContainer being undefined, but the function that you call on it. Polymer does not support this type of function calls in data-binding. From the docs:

Data binding binds a property or sub-property of a custom element (the host element) to a property or attribute of an element in its local DOM (the child or target element).

You are calling a function on a property, which does not work. If you want to call a function, you could to this with computed bindings.

<menu-list for="places" data="{{getData(dataContainer.*)}}">

However, this assumes that your menu-list is placed in some parent Polymer element and I'm not sure if this is the case here as you use a dom-bind. However, if you do have a parent element you could then add the computed function there.

Polymer({
    is: 'parent-element',
    properties: {dataContainer: ....},
    getData: function() {
        return dataContainer.getSomeData();
    }

});

getData will be called anytime dataContainer or its sub-properties change.

title: Polymer refresh the property's value which is calculated by a method
body:
We are currently working on a project, in which we use a combination of AngularJS and Polymer.

We have some structure, but what's really important is this piece of code:

<template is="dom-bind" angupoly="{dataContainer:'dataContainer'}">
    <menu-list for="places" data="{{dataContainer.getSomeData()}}">
</template>

We have a variable defined on $scope named dataContainer, which is being set in a controller. The problem is that this code is executed before the controller prepares that property, so it's undefined - it throws:

[dom-bind::_annotatedComputationEffect]: compute method dataContainer.getSomeData() not defined

And the data are never refreshed again and it does not work. On the contrary, with a property it works (it does not matter if it's first state is undefined), it is refreshed.

Because it's a really important point in our application, we wanna ask. How to reach required behaviour?

Thanks, have a nice day! :)

title: Calling an action from a different reducer with React and redux
body:
I got 2 components; A market and a status. The status component manage the amount of money the user have and the market have buttons to buy some stuff. When i click on the button (in the market component), i want my money to decrement.

How can i achieve this the best way possible?

This is my App component who has the Market and Status:

import React from 'react';
import { Link } from 'react-router';
import { connect } from 'react-redux';
import { bindActionCreators } from 'redux';
import * as MarketActions from '../actions/market-actions';
import * as StatusActions from '../actions/status-actions';

import Market from './Market.react';
import Status from './Status.react';

export default class App extends React.Component {
  render() {
    const { dispatch, market, status } = this.props;

    return (
      <div>
        <h1>App</h1>
        <Link to='/'>App</Link>{' '}<Link to='/home'>Home</Link>
        <Status status={status} {...bindActionCreators(StatusActions, dispatch)} />
        <Market market={market} {...bindActionCreators(MarketActions, dispatch)} {...bindActionCreators(StatusActions, dispatch)} />
        {this.props.children}
      </div>
    );
  }
}

export default connect(state => ({ market: state.market, status: state.status }))(App);

I bound the actions from the status on the market component (i feel it's not the right thing to do, but it worked).

After this, i handle these actions in the Market component on a click of a button like this:

handleBuyClick(e) {
  let { index, price } = e.target.dataset;
  index = parseInt(index);
  price = parseInt(price);

  this.props.buyItem(index);
  this.props.changeMoney(price); //this bugs me, i think it don't belongs there
}

Is there a better way?

Thank you

answers.title: backbonejs cookie not maintained across cross domains
answers.body:
It is not clear on this piece of code but looks like your calls are going to different domains (once you mentioned CORS).

If that is really the case, I am afraid session and cookie might be different because they are probably specific only to the domain that your 1st request (doLogin) reached but not the 2nd request (fetch). More info: Sharing cookies across different domains and different applications (classic ASP and ASP.NET)

Another thing to look is if your both servers REALLY support CORS because one part of the setup is client-side and another is server-side (headers). More info on: http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/cors/

comments.body: Change the commas to semicolons in your for loop: for (i = 0 ; i < 5 ; i++).

Also, make sure to declare all your variables.  You have not declared i, so it could stomp on a global variable.  Use element.textContent instead of element.innerHTML whenever possible. It's faster, since it doesn't have to parse tags or special characters.

answers.title: How do I make this array into a list using getElementById and innerHTML?
answers.body:
you could grab the containing div results and creating a ul like this var locations = $('<ul>') and then creating a function that loops through you array and within each iteration creates a li and it's content then appends it to the ul, and finally at the end appends the ul to the container div. Here is a rough version of what that might look like in jQuery. Same concept in JS slightly different syntax.

var results = $('#results');
var list = $('<ul>');

function processPlaces() {
      for (i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
          var listItem = $('<li>');
          listItem.text(places[i]); 
          list.append(listItem);
      }
     results.append(list);
  }

this dynamic approach may be better so that as you add stuff to the array you do not need to go back to the html and manually add more li's each time.

answers.title: How do I make this array into a list using getElementById and innerHTML?
answers.body:
Your problem is that you're using commas , instead of semicolon ; in your for loop:

for (i = 0, i < 5, i++) {

It should be:

for (var i = 0; i < 5; i++) {

Note: I've inserted the var keyword, because it's better to declare the variable inside the loop, avoiding the implicit declaration of i into the global context.

answers.title: How do I make this array into a list using getElementById and innerHTML?
answers.body:
Pure and plain solution:

One can access the list items through the id of the <div>:

<div id="results">
    <ul>
        <li></li>
        <li></li>
        <li></li>
        <li></li>
        <li></li>
    </ul>
</div>

Access lists with children:

var results = document.getElementById("results");
var lists = results.children[0].children;

Lists is a HTML collection with all <li> elements. Access all <li>:

for(var i = 0; i < lists.length; i += 1) {
    lists[i].innerHTML = places[i];
}

Example

answers.title: Inheritance in Waterline ORM
answers.body:
It looks like it isn't supported out-of-the-box by Waterline. See this GitHub issue.

One of the comments in the above issue also links to a sailscast video on YouTube (here). In a nutshell, the video walks through using lodash to merge the child model with the base model, like so:

baseModel.js

module.exports = {
  attributes : {
    name : 'STRING',
    age  : 'INTEGER'
  },
  foo : function () {}
}

childModel.js

var baseModel = require('/path/to/baseModel')
  , _ = require('lodash')

module.exports = _.merge(baseModel, {
  attributes : {
    birthDate : 'DATE',
    ...
  }
})

comments.body: self.errors = [{status: 404}, {status: 405}, …];?

There is an easy way to add properties to objects: just assign them, like self.errors.newProperty = newValue. Only one property can be called “error”, though, so your structure doesn’t make a lot of sense.
prototype error, instantiate errors in each object instance
You could make the status value be the key instead of just the word "error".

Create an array by using square braces [] and then add your error objects to it. Of course, if your intention is to look up errors by status, then it probably makes more sense to have an object which is keyed off the status: self.errors = { 404 : 'missing', 405: 'whatever' } for example.
i think {404: "missing", 500: "oops" ... } would be a lot more useful than searching arrays... what matt said...
@dandavis—until the second 404…

@RobG: even if that were in an array, how would you know "which" 404 error was which based on the primitives shown by OP? in short, the 2nd 404 doesn't make sense, there's only one afaik. if he had a path or something i'll conced, but with just what's shown, an AoO is inapropos
@dandavis—arrays have a sequence, and one of the properties can be the time of the error. Many error logs are simple text files with errors added to the bottom. I expect the OP is just an example.

Thanks for the comments guys. I probably should have mentioned that the errors object im using will be dynamically populated and isnt set to just https status codes. It will contain a multitude of errors ranging from http statuses to form validation warnings.

answers.title: Using an Array instead of an Object in JS
answers.body:
I would recommend the following structure, It'll be easy to access each property:

self.errors = {
    404: "not found",
    500: "error text"
};

title: Using an Array instead of an Object in JS
body:
I have the below object being declared in my application:

self.errors = {
    error: {
        status: 404,
        text: 'Missing!'
    }
};

Now the above object is aiming to grow with each error triggered by the user, as to provide a list of errors.

Now as far as I am aware, there isn't an easy way for me to add additional error properties to this errors object (so I could have one for 405 etc).

But my experience with arrays is very limited. Is there a similar format I could use in an array that I could just push additional error sections to the array?

This is assuming there is no easy way to add properties to objects.

Edit: The user's actions will generate this list of errors meaning I can't just use the following structure:

self.errors = {
404: "not found",
500: "error text"
};

Because the the list will just grow pretty much indefinitely as they keep triggering errors.

title: How to obtain value of textbox within jQuery Mobile Listview control
body:

Since the data-filter property is true, the control creates a textbox for filtering:

I need to know how to obtain the value of that textbox. I've tried both $("#txtTo").val() and $("#txtTo").text() but both return "".

Nothing in the docs seem to indicate how to obtain the current filter value, and I've dug through the properties in the Chrome debugger to no avail. Any ideas?

I have a sinking suspicion the answer is to use my own <input>, listen to whenever the value changes, and update a separate listview control instead and not use data-filter.
